The Journal discovered several examples of Amazon's investments leading to in-house product development. LivingSocial, a deals website, told the Journal that after Amazon took a 30% stake in the company, it began requesting troves of data from the company, hiring away employees, and contacting LivingSocial's clients to offer better deals. Amazon later settled with Nucleus for $5 million but did not admit any wrongdoing, according to the report. Other companies, like DefinedCrowd, Vocalife, and Ubi ‚Äî which made a voice-operated speaker similar to the Echo ‚Äî also told the Journal Amazon had met with them or invested in them, then later seemed to use their technology. In many instances, the smaller companies said they could no longer compete in the space, and downsized or closed.
